citations.narrative:
There were 2 birds that escaped the walk-through aviary and were either not recovered or found dead. A quail escaped
on March 8, 2024 and was found dead March 10, 2024. A budgie escaped on May 6, 2024 when both doors of the
entrance were opened and was not recovered. The aviary has a double door entrance and chains in the opening of the
inner doorway but birds can escape when both doors are opened.
Failure to employ adequate security measures to contain the birds can result in escape and/or death.
Housing facilities must employ security measures that contain the birds securely.

There was one emu enclosure where members of the public could walk up to the enclosure fence and contact the animal
with no readily identifiable attendant and no barriers present.
Unattended public contact does not ensure safe public interaction with these animals.
The licensee must ensure attendants are present at all time during periods of public contact.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by July 6, 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and
must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
